statement.tex: %text Find the coordinate of the point, where the line $\dfrac{x-2}{3}=\dfrac{y+1}{4}=\dfrac{z-2}{2}$ intersects the plane $x-y+z-5=0$. Also find the angle between the line and the plane %

step.context: \begin{align} \dfrac{x-2}{3}=\dfrac{y+1}{4}&=\dfrac{z-2}{2} \\ x-y+z-5&=0 \end{align} \\ %text Are the two equations above sufficient to find the intersection point between the line and the plane? If so what is it? %
step.tex: %text No, they are not. We need three equations to find three variables (x, y and z), which form the coordinates of the intersection point. %
step.reason: \dfrac{x-2}{3}=\dfrac{y+1}{4}=\dfrac{z-2}{2} \\ %text The above equation for a line is actually two distinct equations. % \begin{align} \qquad\dfrac{x-2}{3}=\dfrac{y+1}{4} \text{ and } \dfrac{y+1}{4}=\dfrac{z-2}{2}. \end{align} \\ %text Therefore, the two equations above along with the equation of the plane $x-y+z=5$ are sufficient to solve for x, y and z. %

step.context: \begin{align} \dfrac{x-2}{3}=\dfrac{y+1}{4}&=\dfrac{z-2}{2} \\ x-y+z-5&=0 \end{align} \\ %text What is the point of intersection of the line and plane shown above? %
step.reason: %text To find the intersection points we can write x, y and z in terms of a variable k and substitute k into the equation of the plane. % \dfrac{x-2}{3}=\dfrac{y+1}{4}=\dfrac{z-2}{2}=k \\ \begin{align} &(3k+2)-(4k-1)+(2k+2)-5=0 \\ \implies& k=0. \\ \implies&x=2, y=-1, z=2 \end{align} \\ %text The line and plane intersect at $(2,-1,2)$. %

step.context: %text If $(2,-1,2)$ lies on plane the $x-y+z=5$, what is the equation of the normal to the plane at this point? %
